Setup¶

Where you learn about variables, if-statements, and loops.

Day 2¶

Solution for Day 1

  1. Install python:

There are (unfortunately) many ways to install python. If you are on Windows, you might have searched for “How to install python on Windows?”, which leads you to this page. After clicking on “Latest Python 3 Release”, you end up on this page. Although it doesn’t look like it, you are in the right place. Just scroll down, past the Monty Python joke that you are too young to understand and find a link that says “Windows x86-64 executable installer”. Download and execute the installer. You now have python installed.

  1. Install pycharm:

This one is simpler: Just follow the links to download pycharm for your operating system and install it.

  1. Open pycharm and create a new project called “quemono”:

There is really not much more to do than to follow the steps proposed by pycharm. Enter the name “quemono” for the project when asked for it. If you went with the defaults, you end up having a project with a simple program generated for you. Delete the lines in that program, we don’t need them.

  1. Write your first program that prints “¡Hola Mono!”

The python command to print text is called print. It is a function and just like in math, we give it arguments in round parentheses. The text we want to print has to be enclosed in quotation marks. All together, this gives:

print("¡Hola Mono!")

¡Hola Mono!

Write a program that asks for your name and then says “!Hola <your name>!”.

  1. Learn about the input function.

  2. Use input to read the name and print to produce the message.
